thread.title: Willowridge, Ridge Point join Texas City atop 23-5A
thread.title_full: Willowridge, Ridge Point join Texas City atop 23-5A

author: Jack Marrion
title: Willowridge, Ridge Point join Texas City atop 23-5A
text:
HCN file photo Willowridge, Ridge Point join Texas City atop 23-5A 
Chad Zeno (37) and Willowridge are tied with Ridge Point and Texas City atop District 23-5A. The Eagles defeated Santa Fe 25-7 to improve to 3-2 overall, 2-0 in district. Advertisement Willowridge, Ridge Point join Texas City atop 23-5A By Jack Marrion Houston   
The Willowridge football team has already tripled last year’s victory total, and the season is only half over. The Eagles stuffed Santa Fe 25-7 for their third win, Oct. 3 at Hall Stadium. 
Willowridge improved to 3-2 overall, 2-0 in District 23-5A. It is the Eagles’ third 2-0 start to district play in four years. They won a 31-29 thriller against Bush the previous week. 
The Eagles are tied with defending champion Ridge Point and Texas City for first place. The Panthers dropped Bush 55-21 and Texas City edged Marshall 28-21. Elkins defeated Ball 21-13 to improve to 1-1. 
Down 7-0 early, Willowridge shut out Santa Fe for the remaining 44 minutes. Chad Zeno’s first of two touchdown runs brought Willowridge within 7-6, and Jeremiah Sanders’ touchdown produced a 12-7 halftime lead. 
The Willowridge defense forced six turnovers and took over the game in the second half, with Donald Mitchell and Lakedrick Allen both intercepting two passes. The Eagles added a fumble recovery. 
Zeno gave Willowridge an 18-7 lead with 4:29 remaining. Willie Rhodes kept the drives going with multiple long runs, gaining 102 yards on 13 carries. J’Andre Tassain and Rondell Mars combined for seven catches and 116 yards. 
The Eagles put the game away when Allen picked his second pass deep in Santa Fe territory and returned it for the game’s final touchdown. 
An improved Willowridge team has five games to clinch its first playoff berth since 2009. Up next is a test against Elkins, Oct. 9 at Hall Stadium. 
Ridge Point (3-2 overall) had little trouble with Bush (1-4, 0-2), leading 27-0 after the first quarter. Terry Petry caught a 22-yard touchdown from Shane Gosson, B.J. Rainford ran for two touchdowns and Ar’mani Johnson returned an interception for a score, all in the first 10 minutes. 
Rainford had another big game, amassing 174 yards and four touchdowns on 25 carries. Cameron Edmonson was equally successful on nine carries, racking up 83 yards and a score. Gosson threw two touchdown passes, the second to Mustapha Muhammad. 
Ridge Point looks to extend its winning streak to four Oct. 9 at Santa Fe. 
Courtland Neal caught a touchdown pass from Wade Freeman and ran for another to lead Bush, which has a key game against Marshall, Oct. 8 at Mercer Stadium. 
Elkins football team rebounded from an unexpected loss to open District 23-5A play. The Knights’ defense dominated previously-undefeated Ball in a 21-13 victory Oct. 2 at Courville Stadium in Galveston. 
Elkins (4-1, 1-1) clung to a one-point lead with four minutes remaining when Romanon Skinner broke free for a 28-yard touchdown. The Knights had allowed a fourth-quarter field goal as Ball pulled within 14-13, but a fourth-down pass breakup in the end zone was key to maintaining the lead. 
Elkins took almost a half to score but took a 7-3 lead into the break on Romellus Skinner’s touchdown run. Shemick Watts added a four-yard run in the third quarter and the Knights held on despite Ball (4-1, 1-1) scoring 10 unanswered points. 
Texas City (3-2) overcame a rally from its second consecutive Fort Bend ISD opponent to defeat Marshall (2-3, 0-2). 
The Buffalos tied the game with 7:15 remaining on Henry Thomas’ touchdown and conversion receptions, both from Jeremy Smith. But the Stingarees won on a 59-yard touchdown run with 1:43 left. 
Smith had arguably his best game of the season under center, leading the Buffalos with 112 rushing yards and 167 passing yards. He threw two touchdown passes to Thomas and another two Jakobe Sheffield.
